title: Ze'ev
text:
Ze'ev ( zeév), also spelled Zev, is a name of Hebrew origin which means <a href="wolf">wolf</a>. The <a href="given%20name">given name</a> is a masculine form used among <a href="Ashkenazi%20Jews">Ashkenazi Jews</a>. It is a <a href="Bible">Biblical</a> name, adapted from a reference to <a href="Benjamin">Benjamin</a> in <a href="Book%20of%20Genesis">Genesis</a> as a "wolf that raveneth". It re-appeared in relatively recent times as a translation of the <a href="Yiddish%20language">Yiddish</a> name װאָלף "Volf" or "Wolf". The name "Wolf" (in <a href="German%20language">German</a>) was relatively common among <a href="German%20people">German</a>s.
The Bible mentions a person directly named Ze'ev, one of the <a href="Midian">Midian</a>ite leaders defeated by the Judge <a href="Gideon">Gideon</a> (see <a href="Oreb%20and%20Zeeb">Oreb and Zeeb</a>). However, the identical modern name is not derived from this character, an ancient enemy whom later Jews had no reason to emulate.
